22M.2.sl.TZ1.1a(ii).excerpt: State the block of the periodic table in which magnesium is located.
specification: When heated in air, magnesium ribbon reacts with oxygen to form magnesium oxide.

The reaction in (a)(i) was carried out in a crucible with a lid and the following data was recorded:
Mass of crucible and lid = 47.372 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and magnesium ribbon before heating = 53.726 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and product after heating = 56.941 ±0.001 g

When magnesium is burnt in air, some of it reacts with nitrogen to form magnesium nitride according to the equation:
3 Mg (s) + N2 (g) → Mg3N2 (s)
The presence of magnesium nitride can be demonstrated by adding water to the product. It is hydrolysed to form magnesium hydroxide and ammonia.
Most nitride ions are 14N3–.

questions.content: Write a balanced equation for the reaction that occurs.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: Do not accept equilibrium arrows. Ignore state symbols

questions.content: State the block of the periodic table in which magnesium is located.
questions.label: a(ii)

questions.content: Identify a metal, in the same period as magnesium, that does not form a basic oxide.
questions.label: a(iii)

questions.content: Calculate the amount of magnesium, in mol, that was used.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.content: Determine the percentage uncertainty of the mass of product after heating.
questions.label: b(ii)

questions.content: Assume the reaction in (a)(i) is the only one occurring and it goes to completion, but some product has been lost from the crucible. Deduce the percentage yield of magnesium oxide in the crucible.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: Accept alternative methods to arrive at the correct answer.

questions.content: Evaluate whether this, rather than the loss of product, could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(i)
markscheme:
yes
AND
«each Mg combines with23N, so» mass increase would be 14x23which is less than expected increase of 16x
OR
3 mol Mg would form 101g of Mg3N2 but would form 3 x MgO = 121 g of MgO
OR
0.2614 mol forms 10.536 g of MgO, but would form 8.796 g of Mg3N2 ✔
Accept Yes AND “the mass of N/N2 that combines with each g/mole of Mg is lower than that of O/O2”
Accept YES AND “molar mass of nitrogen less than of oxygen”.

questions.content: Suggest an explanation, other than product being lost from the crucible or reacting with nitrogen, that could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme:
incomplete reaction
OR
Mg was partially oxidised already
OR
impurity present that evaporated/did not react ✔
Accept answers relating to a higher atomic mass impurity consuming less O/O2.
Do not accept "human error", "wrongly calibrated balance" or other non-chemical reasons.
If answer to (b)(iii) is >100%, accept appropriate reasons, such as product absorbed moisture before being weighed.

Melting points and boiling points of elements 1 to 95

questions.content: Deduce, giving a reason, the group of elements in the periodic table most likely to undergo sublimation.

smallest difference between melting and boiling points
OR
weakest intermolecular forces «in that period» [✔]

questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: density increases «to a maximum in the transition elements» AND then decreases [✔]

questions.content: Suggest, with a reason, whether the lanthanoids or actinoids of the f-block would have the higher density.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme:
actinoids AND density increases down all groups «due to large increase in atomic mass for small increase in atomic volume»
OR
actinoids AND «much» greater atomic mass with similar type of bonding
OR
actinoids AND density «of actinoids» atomic number 90 to 95 is greater than corresponding lanthanoids [✔]
Note:Accept “actinoids AND on graph actinoids have «much» greater density than lanthanoids”.

questions.content: Compare the ease of oxidation of s-block and d-block metals to their melting points and densities. Use section 25 of the data booklet.

markscheme:
Alternative 1:
«metals with» low densities oxidize easier [✔]
«metals with» low melting points oxidize easier [✔]

Alternative 2:
in s-block «metals with» high densities oxidize easier
OR
in s-block «metals with» low melting points oxidize easier [✔]

in d-block «metals with» low densities oxidize easier
OR
in d-block «metals with» low melting points oxidize easier [✔]
Note:Award [1 max] for “s-block metals more easily oxidized” OR “s-block metals have lower melting points” OR “s-block metals have lower densities”.

22M.2.sl.TZ1.1a(iii).excerpt: Identify a metal, in the same period as magnesium, that does not form a basic oxide.
specification: When heated in air, magnesium ribbon reacts with oxygen to form magnesium oxide.

The reaction in (a)(i) was carried out in a crucible with a lid and the following data was recorded:
Mass of crucible and lid = 47.372 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and magnesium ribbon before heating = 53.726 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and product after heating = 56.941 ±0.001 g

When magnesium is burnt in air, some of it reacts with nitrogen to form magnesium nitride according to the equation:
3 Mg (s) + N2 (g) → Mg3N2 (s)
The presence of magnesium nitride can be demonstrated by adding water to the product. It is hydrolysed to form magnesium hydroxide and ammonia.
Most nitride ions are 14N3–.

questions.content: Write a balanced equation for the reaction that occurs.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: Do not accept equilibrium arrows. Ignore state symbols

questions.content: State the block of the periodic table in which magnesium is located.
questions.label: a(ii)

questions.content: Identify a metal, in the same period as magnesium, that does not form a basic oxide.
questions.label: a(iii)

questions.content: Calculate the amount of magnesium, in mol, that was used.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.content: Determine the percentage uncertainty of the mass of product after heating.
questions.label: b(ii)

questions.content: Assume the reaction in (a)(i) is the only one occurring and it goes to completion, but some product has been lost from the crucible. Deduce the percentage yield of magnesium oxide in the crucible.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: Accept alternative methods to arrive at the correct answer.

questions.content: Evaluate whether this, rather than the loss of product, could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(i)
markscheme:
yes
AND
«each Mg combines with23N, so» mass increase would be 14x23which is less than expected increase of 16x
OR
3 mol Mg would form 101g of Mg3N2 but would form 3 x MgO = 121 g of MgO
OR
0.2614 mol forms 10.536 g of MgO, but would form 8.796 g of Mg3N2 ✔
Accept Yes AND “the mass of N/N2 that combines with each g/mole of Mg is lower than that of O/O2”
Accept YES AND “molar mass of nitrogen less than of oxygen”.

questions.content: Suggest an explanation, other than product being lost from the crucible or reacting with nitrogen, that could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme:
incomplete reaction
OR
Mg was partially oxidised already
OR
impurity present that evaporated/did not react ✔
Accept answers relating to a higher atomic mass impurity consuming less O/O2.
Do not accept "human error", "wrongly calibrated balance" or other non-chemical reasons.
If answer to (b)(iii) is >100%, accept appropriate reasons, such as product absorbed moisture before being weighed.

Acid–base:
yes AND N3- accepts H+/donates electron pair«s»
OR
yes AND H2O loses H+ «to form OH-»/accepts electron pair«s» ✔
Accept reference to the oxidation state of specific elements not changing.

questions.content: Predict, giving a reason, whether the reduction of ReO4− to [Re(OH)2]2+ would oxidize Fe2+ to Fe3+ in aqueous solution. Use section 24 of the data booklet.
questions.label: e(iii)

no AND ReO4− is a weaker oxidizing agent than Fe3+
